column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#Text=Section1 .
#Text=In the first place, I am of opinion that the complaints
#Text=made by the inhabitants of Charlton and the adjoining
#Text=parishes, and by the Sanitary Committee of the Woolwich
#Text=garrison, of offensive smells, are well foimded.
#Text=Two varieties
#Text=of odour were described to me, both of which were
#Text=said to be sickening, but the one more distinctly acid than
#Text=the other, and the one or the other was said to be perceived
#Text=according to the direction of the wind.
#Text=But all parts of the
#Text=district from which the complaints issued do not suffer
#Text=equally from both varieties of odour.
#Text=It appeared further,
#Text=that the more elevated parts, at a greater or less distance
#Text=from the shore of the river, sutler more than those parts
#Text=which are situated at a lower level and nearer to the shore.
#Text=The description given me by the Commandant at Woolwich,
#Text=and by Dr.
#Text=Gordon, the principal medical officer of the
#Text=2:arrison, was altogether the clearest and most instructive
#Text=that I had received, inasmuch as at the barracks and on the
#Text=barrack field, about a mile from the river and at a considerable
#Text=elevation, each variety of odour is perceptible.
#Text=When
#Text=the wind is in the north-west or north-north-east one variety
#Text=is perceived, and when east- north-east the other variety.
#Text=Dr.
#Text=Gordon states that when travelling down the river from
#Text=Woolwich to Purfleet he has recoo-nised the odour of the
#Text=one variety when passing the manure works of Messrs.
#Text=Lawes at Barking Creek, and that of the other when passing
#Text=the works of Messrs.
#Text=Bevington and Messrs.
#Text=Brown in Erith
#Text=Marshes.
#Text=The odour from the last-named works he compares to
#Text=that which he has perceived in India when passing
#Text=to leeward of the places in which the Hindoos consume, by
#Text=an imperfect cremation, the bodies of their dead.
#Text=The
#Text=odour is putrid as well as sickening.
#Text=A north-east wind
#Text=would bring effluvia towards the barracks from Barking
#Text=Creek, distant 2 miles, while a more easterly wind would
#Text=bring those from Ei-ith Marshes, distant 4^ miles.
#Text=In the
#Text=village of Plumstead, also, there are two varieties of odour
#Text=perceived, according as the wind is in the north or hi the
#Text=north-east ; the one wind blowing from the direction of
#Text=Barking Creek, distant 2 miles, and the other from the
#Text=direction of Erith Marshes, distant 3 miles.
#Text=The Manager of the Southern Outfall Pumping Station
#Text=also distino ' uishes two varieties of offensive odour,
#Text=according as the wind is in the east, bringing efflnvia which he
#Text=describes as intolerably offensive, from the direction of the
#Text=glue and manure works of Messrs.
#Text=Brown and Messrs.
#Text=Bevington, about half a-mile lower down the river; or in
#Text=the west, bringing effluvia from Barking Creek, distant
#Text=about 2 miles (no factory, giving rise to offensive effluvia,
#Text=intervening.)
#Text=On the other hand, at Charlton, it appears,
#Text=from the statements of the Inspectors of Nusiances, that
#Text=only one variety of offensive odour is the subject of complaint,
#Text=that it is of an acid and sickening character, and is
#Text=perceived only when the wind is in the north-west, and,
#Text=therefore; blowing from the direction of a group of factories
#Text=on the north shore near the Victoria Docks, and from some
#Text=factories on the opposite or south shore and situated in
#Text=Greenwich Marshes.
#Text=It thus became necessary that I should inspect the
#Text=several factories between Blackwall Reach to the west, and
#Text=Erith Reach to the east.
#Text=I have marked upon a map, which
#Text=I append to this Report, the situation of these factories.
#Text=It will be seen, on reference to the map,  ' that they lie in
#Text=three groups.
#Text=Group 1 is situated on and near the shores
#Text=of the river at Bugsby ' s reach; group 2 about Barking
#Text=Creek, about 3 miles more to the east ; and group 3 about
#Text=2 or 3 miles still further to the east, about the bend of
#Text=the river between Halfway Reach and Erith Reach.
#Text=The
#Text=effluvia from group 1 alone appear to be complained of by
#Text=the inhabitants of Charlton; the effluvia from groups 1, 2
#Text=and 3 appear to annoy the garrison at Woolwich; while
#Text=those from groups 2 and 3 annoy the inhabitants of Plumstead
#Text=village and of the little colony at the Southern
#Text=Outfall Pumping Station.
#Text=The total number of factories
#Text=in the three groups is twenty-one.
#Text=Group 1 consists of
#Text=ten factories of various kinds, group 2 of four, and group
#Text=3 of seven factories.
#Text=All of these factories are not equally
#Text=offensive; some give issue to effluvia only perceptible at a
#Text=short distance from the works, while the effluvia from others
#Text=are such as experience has shown may be carried by the
#Text=wind to the distance of several miles.
#Text=The observations made in my inspection of each group
#Text=of factories were specially directed to ascertain the extent
#Text=of the works, the duration of their existence, the character
#Text=and amount of effiuvia proceeding from them, and the means
#Text=in use for preventing the escape of offensive effluvia.
#Text=Group 1 consists of the following establishments : —
#Text=
#Text={a.)
#Text=On Greenwich Marshes, on the south side of the
#Text=river —
#Text=
#Text=(1.)
#Text=Mockford ' s  '  '  Ordnance Manure Works (No. 1 on
#Text=map). — Only established about six months.
#Text=No work going
#Text=on at the time of my visit.
#Text=There were about 250 tons of
#Text=shoddy on the premises, a considerable quantity of mineral
#Text=phosphates, and over 5,000 tons of guano.
#Text=It was stated
#Text=that the materials intended to be used are guano, mineral
#Text=phosphates, and sulphate of ammonia.
#Text=It was stated further
#Text=that probably oil of vitriol would also be manufactured.
#Text=The arrangements for preventing the escape of offensive
#Text=effluvia are very imperfect, but, inasmuch as but little work
#Text=has been carried on at these premises up to the present
#Text=time, the effluvia proceeding from them have probably had
#Text=little to do with the complaints
#Text=.
#Text=(2.)
#Text=Hiirs Oil of Vitriol and Manure Works (No. 2 on
#Text=map). — These works cover about three acres.
#Text=They have
#Text=been established here for thirty-eight years, but manures
#Text=have only been manufactured here since 1856.
#Text=There are
#Text=separate works adjoining the manure works for the manufacture
#Text=of nitric acid, tartaric acid, and oxalic acid.
#Text=(a. ) The
#Text=arrangements for preventing escape of acid fumes in the
#Text=manufacture of oil of vitriol appear to be efficient, except
#Text=at times when the denitrating chamber is being washed out,
#Text=which is only occasionally, {h.)
#Text=The materials used in the
#Text=manufacture of manures are shoddy, waste leather, dry
#Text=bones, bone ash, and the refuse from sugar bakeries, coprolites,
#Text=and mineral phosphates generally.
#Text=Until quite
#Text=lately, no means have been in use for preventing the escape
#Text=of offensive effluvia into the atmosphere during the mixing
#Text=of the materials, or subsequently on their discharge from
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=Section2
#Text=.
#Text=(1.)
#Text=Messrs.
#Text=Gihhs"' Oil of Vitriol and Manure Works
#Text=(No. 3 on map). — Established here for twelve or fifteen
#Text=years, {a.)
#Text=crude sulphur, pyrites, and spent oxide from the gas works.
#Text=anthracene is also manufactured.
#Text=Otherwise all the first
#Text=products are sent away from the premises in casks.
#Text=It is
#Text=scarcely probable, however, that these works occasion any
#Text=nuisance to the inhabitants of Plumstead.
#Text=In the manu-*
#Text=facture of sulphate of ammonia from ammoniacal liquor,
#Text=means are in use to prevent the escape of sulphuretted
#Text=hydrogen into the atmosphere.
#Text=Group 3 consists of the following establishments : —
#Text=
#Text=(a) On the south side of Erith Marshes
#Text=.
#Text=(1) Bevington ' s Manicre Works (No. 15 on map.) —
#Text=Situated about half- a- mile from the Southern Outfall Pumping Station.
#Text=These works are small, but have been established several years.
#Text=The material used is " scutch," which
#Text=is the refuse matter left in the pans in which glue is made.
#Text=This material is heated in closed pans by steam, with the
#Text=addition of oil of vitriol, and there is an arrangement for
#Text=condensing the vapours which proceed from the pans.
#Text=Fat
#Text=is first skimmed off, and the residue, after boiling about
#Text=three hours, is run off into  '  '  delves " or trenches about four
#Text=feet deep, dug into the earth outside the works: these
#Text=^ ' delves" are worked alternately.
#Text=Up to about twelve
#Text=months ago the pans employed were open.
#Text=The manure
#Text=which runs as a semi- liquid material into the "delves"
#Text=solidifies in them after a time, partly by evaporation and
#Text=partly by soakage of the more watery parts into the earth.
#Text=When sufficiently firm the manure is dug out and dried by
#Text=spreading it on heated plates, or by heating it over semicircular brick-flues.
#Text=The effluvia from these stoves or flues
#Text=are very offensive indeed, and escape freely into the external
#Text=atmosphere.
#Text=The odour, which resembles that of cheese
#Text=when very much decomposed, pervades the works and their
#Text=neighbourhood
#Text=.
#Text=(2) Broimi ' s Glue and Manure Works (No. 16 on map)
#Text=are carried on in premises adjoining Bevington ' s.
#Text=These
#Text=works have been established a great many years, during
#Text=which they have been a constant source of nuisance to
#Text=persons passing up and down the river.
#Text=Two manufactures
#Text=are carried on here.
#Text=One is that of glue from the clii^pings
#Text=of hides used by tanners, horses '  hoofs, &c.
#Text=These matters
#Text=arrive at the works in a more or less putrid condition, and
#Text=no means whatever are in use to prevent the escape of the
#Text=highly offensive vapour from the pans in which they are
#Text=boiled into the atmosphere outside the works.
#Text=The offensiveness
#Text=of the vapour would naturally vary with the degree
#Text=of decomposition of the material boiled.
#Text=The " scutch "
#Text=which remains after the making of the glue, is dealt with
#Text=as at Bevington ' s Works, the only difference being that no
#Text=means are in use here to condense the vapour proceeding
#Text=from the pans in which the  '  '  scutch " is heated with acid.
#Text=and that no means were in use to prevent the escape of
#Text=offensive effluvia.
#Text=To sum up the inferences I draw from the observation
#Text=made during my inspection of the above works^ I may say^
#Text=that —
#Text=
#Text=(1.)
#Text=It is tolerably certain that the offensive effluvia
#Text=complained of bv the inhabitants of Charlton aud it&
#Text=vicinity, have proceeded from the works upon Greenwich.
#Text=Marshes, and from the other manure works in group 1.
#Text=Perhaps at various times, or occasionally, other effluvia
#Text=from other works than the manure works, have assisted to
#Text=create the nuisance complained of.
#Text=Probably also the
#Text=principal sources of nuisance have been Hill ' s Works on
#Text=Greenwich Marshes and Odam ' s Works on the opposite side
#Text=of the river
#Text=.
#Text=(2.)
#Text=It is tolerably certain that the effluvia complained
#Text=of as proceeding from the direction of Barking Creek, have
#Text=issued mainly from the manure works of Messrs.
#Text=Lawes
#Text=.
#Text=(3) It is absolutely certain that the putrid sickening
#Text=odour proceeding from the direction of group 3 has issued
#Text=mainly from the glue and manure works of Messrs.
#Text=Brown
#Text=and Messrs.
#Text=Bevington on Erith Marshes.
#Text=Perhaps, from
#Text=time to time, other effluvia have been added from the
#Text=manure works on the opposite shore of the river.
#Text=With respect to the influence exerted upon the health
#Text=of the persons who have been exposed to these offensive
#Text=effluvia, and who complain of them as nuisances, little can
#Text=be said of a very definite nature.
#Text=JN^either.
#Text=Dr.
#Text=Finch nor
#Text=Dr, Wise, both of whom stated it as their opinion that the
#Text=effluvia were injurious to health, could furnish me with any
#Text=specific information upon this subject.
#Text=I am aAvare of no
#Text=evidence that the workmen employed in artificial manure
#Text=works suffer in any way from disease referable to the nature
#Text=of their occupation.
#Text=Nevertheless, delicate persons, and
#Text=even some healthy persons, are very susceptible to the
#Text=influence of sickening odours, such as those given off from
#Text=the works complained of.
#Text=Such persons are "upset" by
#Text=them, made sick or nauseated, and, to such an extent as
#Text=this, may be said to have their health disturbed.
#Text=Dr.
#Text=Gordon stated to me in conversation that, in the event of
#Text=any severe epidemic occurring, evil would, in his opinion,
#Text=probably result from these nuisances, on the principle that
#Text=anything which  '  '  upsets " the nervous system predisposes
#Text=an individual to suiter.
#Text=crude sulphur, pyrites, and spent oxide from the gas works.
#Text=anthracene is also manufactured.
#Text=Otherwise all the first
#Text=products are sent away from the premises in casks.
#Text=It is
#Text=scarcely probable, however, that these works occasion any
#Text=nuisance to the inhabitants of Plumstead.
#Text=In the manu-*
#Text=facture of sulphate of ammonia from ammoniacal liquor,
#Text=means are in use to prevent the escape of sulphuretted
#Text=hydrogen into the atmosphere.
#Text=Group 3 consists of the following establishments : —
#Text=
#Text=(a) On the south side of Erith Marshes
#Text=.
#Text=(1) Bevington ' s Manicre Works (No. 15 on map.) —
#Text=Situated about half- a- mile from the Southern Outfall Pumping Station.
#Text=These works are small, but have been established several years.
#Text=The material used is " scutch," which
#Text=is the refuse matter left in the pans in which glue is made.
#Text=This material is heated in closed pans by steam, with the
#Text=addition of oil of vitriol, and there is an arrangement for
#Text=condensing the vapours which proceed from the pans.
#Text=Fat
#Text=is first skimmed off, and the residue, after boiling about
#Text=three hours, is run off into  '  '  delves " or trenches about four
#Text=feet deep, dug into the earth outside the works: these
#Text=^ ' delves" are worked alternately.
#Text=Up to about twelve
#Text=months ago the pans employed were open.
#Text=The manure
#Text=which runs as a semi- liquid material into the "delves"
#Text=solidifies in them after a time, partly by evaporation and

#Text=When sufficiently firm the manure is dug out and dried by

#Text=are very offensive indeed, and escape freely into the external
#Text=atmosphere.
#Text=The odour, which resembles that of cheese
#Text=when very much decomposed, pervades the works and their
#Text=neighbourhood
#Text=.
#Text=(2) Broimi ' s Glue and Manure Works (No. 16 on map)
#Text=are carried on in premises adjoining Bevington ' s.
#Text=These
#Text=works have been established a great many years, during
#Text=which they have been a constant source of nuisance to
#Text=persons passing up and down the river.
#Text=Two manufactures
#Text=are carried on here.
#Text=One is that of glue from the clii^pings
#Text=of hides used by tanners, horses '  hoofs, &c.
#Text=These matters
#Text=arrive at the works in a more or less putrid condition, and
#Text=no means whatever are in use to prevent the escape of the
#Text=highly offensive vapour from the pans in which they are
#Text=boiled into the atmosphere outside the works.
#Text=The offensiveness
#Text=of the vapour would naturally vary with the degree
#Text=of decomposition of the material boiled.
#Text=The " scutch "
#Text=which remains after the making of the glue, is dealt with
#Text=as at Bevington ' s Works, the only difference being that no
#Text=means are in use here to condense the vapour proceeding
#Text=from the pans in which the  '  '  scutch " is heated with acid.
#Text=and that no means were in use to prevent the escape of
#Text=offensive effluvia.
#Text=To sum up the inferences I draw from the observation
#Text=made during my inspection of the above works^ I may say^
#Text=that —
#Text=
#Text=(1.)
#Text=It is tolerably certain that the offensive effluvia
#Text=complained of bv the inhabitants of Charlton aud it&
#Text=vicinity, have proceeded from the works upon Greenwich.
#Text=Marshes, and from the other manure works in group 1.
#Text=Perhaps at various times, or occasionally, other effluvia
#Text=from other works than the manure works, have assisted to
#Text=create the nuisance complained of.
#Text=Probably also the
#Text=principal sources of nuisance have been Hill ' s Works on
#Text=Greenwich Marshes and Odam ' s Works on the opposite side
#Text=of the river
#Text=.
#Text=(2.)
#Text=It is tolerably certain that the effluvia complained
#Text=of as proceeding from the direction of Barking Creek, have
#Text=issued mainly from the manure works of Messrs.
#Text=Lawes
#Text=.
#Text=(3) It is absolutely certain that the putrid sickening
#Text=odour proceeding from the direction of group 3 has issued
#Text=mainly from the glue and manure works of Messrs.
#Text=Brown
#Text=and Messrs.
#Text=Bevington on Erith Marshes.
#Text=Perhaps, from
#Text=time to time, other effluvia have been added from the
#Text=manure works on the opposite shore of the river.
#Text=With respect to the influence exerted upon the health
#Text=of the persons who have been exposed to these offensive
#Text=effluvia, and who complain of them as nuisances, little can
#Text=be said of a very definite nature.
#Text=JN^either.
#Text=Dr.
#Text=Finch nor
#Text=Dr, Wise, both of whom stated it as their opinion that the
#Text=effluvia were injurious to health, could furnish me with any
#Text=specific information upon this subject.
#Text=I am aAvare of no
#Text=evidence that the workmen employed in artificial manure
#Text=works suffer in any way from disease referable to the nature

#Text=Nevertheless, delicate persons, and
#Text=even some healthy persons, are very susceptible to the
